Let $k\geq 3$. What is the maximum number of edges that a graph on $n$ vertices can contain if it does not have a $k$-regular subgraph? Is it $\ll n^{1+o(1)}$?



Asked by Erd\H{o}s and Sauer. Resolved by Janzer and Sudakov \cite{JaSu23}, who proved that there exists some $C=C(k)>0$ such that any graph on $n$ vertices with at least $Cn\log\log n$ edges contains a $k$-regular subgraph.

A construction due to Pyber, R\"{o}dl, and Szemer\'{e}di \cite{PRS95} shows that this is best possible.

In \cite{Er75} Erd\H{o}s mentions a similar question of Szemer\'{e}di, in which the $k$-regular subgraph must be connected. Let $F(n,k)$ be the smallest number of edges on $n$ vertices which guarantee a connected $k$-regular subgraph. Erd\H{o}s \cite{Er75} proved $F(n,3) \ll n^{5/3}$.




References


[Er75] Erd\H{o}s, P., Some recent progress on extremal problems in graph theory. Congr. Numer. (1975), 3-14.

[JaSu23] Janzer, Oliver and Sudakov, Benny, Resolution of the {E}rd\H{o}s-{S}auer problem on regular
subgraphs. Forum Math. Pi (2023), Paper No. e19, 13.

[PRS95] Pyber, L. and R\"{o}dl, V. and Szemer\'{e}di, E., Dense subgraphs without 3-regular subgraphs. Journal of Combinatorial Theory, Series B (1995), 41-54.
